'''Johann Jacob Grasser''' (24 February 1579 – 20 March 1627) was a scholar and [[polyhistor]] of [[Basel]]. He studied theology and was active as a poet, in the sciences and in geography. He was ''Magister Artium'' and ''[[poet laureate|Poeta laureatus]]'' in Basel in 1601. He travelled across Switzerland and in Europe during 1603 to 1608. When he was in [[Nîmes]], he wrote a treatise on the Roman antiquities there which was reprinted several times. In 1607, he was given the title of [[Count Palatine (Imperial)|Count Palatine]]<ref>in the [[Holy Roman Empire]] at the time an honorary rank sometimes bestowed on poets and scholars</ref> by the [[Imperial Commissioner]] in [[Padua]], from which time he styled himself as ''Ioannes Iacobus Grasserus, Civis Romanus, Comes Palatinus''.
He was pastor in [[Bennwil]] and [[Hölstein]] during 1610 to 1612, and sacristan at [[Theodorskirche (Basel)|St. Theodore church]] in Basel during 1612 to 1627. He published various editions and translations, besides his own works of moderate Calvinist theology, historiography and travel literature. His 1624 [[historiography of Switzerland|Swiss]] ''Heldenbuch'' is without historiographical value but noted for its social criticism.
==Works== *1607 (on the Roman antiquities at [[Nîmes]]) ''De antiquitatibus Nemausensibus dissertatio'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=BN8-AAAAcAAJ] **repeatedly reprinted, in 1614 with some of Grasser's poetry, ''Poëmata: accessit De antiquitatibus Nemausensibus dissertatio''[https://books.google.com/books?id=yDETAAAAQAAJ] *1610 (travel literature) ''Newe und volkommne Italianische Frantzösische und Englische Schatzkamer: Das ist: Wahrhaffte und eigendtliche Beschreibung aller Stätten in Italia Sicilia Sardinia Corsica Franckreich Engelland und darumb ligenden Provintzen: wie auch der denckwürdigsten Sachen so sich daselbsten jemahln zugetragen''[https://books.google.com/books?id=lbNBAAAAcAAJ][https://books.google.com/books?id=sNM-AAAAcAAJ] *1618 (theology) ''Speculum theologiae mysticae. Sive Dissertationes, et meditationes allegoricae: quibus pleraque vtriusque testamenti mysteria, ex ipsis sacris literis, patribus, aliisque tam modernis, quam veteribus doctoribus varios in usus explicantur & illustrantur'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=or-y1Iq0OZUC] *1618 (pamphlet) ''Petri Calvi tridentini jur. utriusq. doct. oratio renuntiatoria, Basileae'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=K-H9GwAACAAJ] *1619 (pamphlet on the [[Great Comet of 1618]]) ''Christliches Bedencken vber den Erschrockenlichen Cometen, So verschienen Novemb. Vnd Decemb. Ann. 1618'' (1664 ed. ''Christenliches Bedencken auch natuerlicher, historischer und schrifftmaessigen Bericht von dem erschrocklichen Cometen der in dem ausslauffenden 1618. Jahr sich in Europa sehen lassen'') *1624 (historiography) ''Schweitzerisch Helden Buch: darinn die denkwürdigste Thaten und Sachen gemeiner loblicher Eydgnossschafft, alss Regiments Enderungen, Befreyungen, Krieg, Schlachten, Vertrag, Bündnussen, und andre namhaffte Handlungen, wie zugleich der fürnembsten Patrioten Lebensbeschreibungen : nicht nur auss allerhandt getruckten : sondern auch auss drey fürnemmen alten geschriebenen Chronicken, zu auffmunterung der alten Eydgnosssischen Dapfferkeit, und Beschirmung der theror erworbenen Freyheit''[https://books.google.com/books?id=BAtAAAAAcAAJ] *1623 (historiography) ''Waldenser Chronick von den Verfolgungen so die Waldenser, Albigenser, Picarder und Hussiten''[https://books.google.com/books?id=LCUDAAAAcAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Johann+Jacob+Grasser%22&hl=de&source=gbs_navlinks_s] *1624 (historiography) ''Historischer Lustgarten: Mit den denckwürdigsten Historien und Sachen gezieret, etc'' *1624 (historiography, geography)''Itinerarium historico-politicum, quod ex inclyta ad Moen. Francofordia per celebriores Helvetiae et regni Arelatensis urbes in uniuersam extenditur Italiam'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=rxYPAAAAQAAJ] *(1636) (pamphlet) ''Ein Christenliche Trewhertzige wolmeynende warnung, Anmahnung vnd erjnerrung: An alle Menschen'' *(1672) (theology) ''Christlicher In Gottes Wort gegründeter aber mißdeuteter und übel auffgenommener Predigten erstes Par: Worinnen gehandelt wird Erstlich/ Vom Ampt der Kirchen und Seelen-Wachtern. Auß dem Propheten Ezechiel c. 3. v. 17- 21. Demnach von dem Danck/ welchen getreue Prediger und Seelen-Wachter von der Welt/ gemeinlich zu gewarten haben. Auß dem Propheten Amos c. 7, v. 10-17.''
;editions *1605 ''Polyhistor vel Rerum toto orbe memorabilium thesaurus'' ([[Gaius Julius Solinus]])[https://books.google.com/books?id=NYw9AAAAcAAJ] *1609 ''P. Papinii Statii opera quae extant omnia'' ([[Publius Papinius Statius]])[https://books.google.com/books?id=kqM_AAAAcAAJ] *1617 ''Epithetorum opus perfectissimum'' ([[Ravisius Textor]]) [https://books.google.com/books?id=0ZBEAAAAcAAJ]
;translations *1610 ''Opera didactica, Lehr- u. Trostreicher Tractat '' ([[Pierre Dumoulin]]) *1615 ''Zwo merckliche und dieser Zeit sehr lesenswürdige Missiven: Eine an König in Frankreich, die andre an Papst zu Rom : Betreffendt ein wohlbedenckliche Reformation der Jesuiten '' ([[Théophile Raynaud]]) [https://books.google.com/books?id=bp9GAAAAcAAJ]

{{Infobox journal | title = Journal of Anthropological Archaeology | cover = Journal of Anthropological Archaeology.gif | editor = J.M. O'Shea | discipline = [[Archaeology]] | peer-reviewed = | language = English | former_names = | abbreviation = J. Anthropol. Archaeol. | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | country = | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1982-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 1.906 | impact-year = 2014 | website = http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.cws_home/622852/description | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | JSTOR = | OCLC = 637806874 | LCCN = 82644021 | CODEN = | ISSN = 0278-4165 | eISSN = | boxwidth = }} The '''''Journal of Anthropological Archaeology''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] in the field of [[archaeology]]. The journal was founded in 1982, appears four times per year, and is published by [[Elsevier]]. Since its beginnings, the ''Journal of Anthropological Archaeology'' has produced 40 volumes. The current editor is John O'Shea (University of Michigan). Publications in the journal focus on understanding the operation, organization, and evolution of human societies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.elsevier.com/wps/find/journaldescription.cws_home/622852/description#description |title=About the journal |publisher=Elsevier |work=Journal of Anthropological Archaeology |accessdate=2010-08-30}}</ref> Contributions to the journal are not limited to those submissions by archaeologists only. Contributions from practitioners from fields and sub disciplines that complement the interests of the ''Journal of Anthropological Archaeology'' readership are commonplace. Articles may be published from ethnologists, ecologists, sociologists, and evolutionary biologists, in addition to archaeologists.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Journal of Anthropological Archaeology {{!}} 0278-4165 {{!}} Elsevier|url = http://www.elsevier.com/journals/journal-of-anthropological-archaeology/0278-4165/guide-for-authors#94100|website = www.elsevier.com|accessdate = 2015-09-01|last = Elsevier}}</ref> The data expressed in the journal ranges from early archaeological evidence of human culture to work by contemporary ethnographers.<ref name=":0" />
== Content Access == Authors have the option to choose between publishing their content as open access articles which allow the general public to access the information, or subscription access only. Subscription access only allows the article to be viewed by paying journal subscribers. Elsevier applies the same peer review criterion to articles regardless of the author's publication access decision.<ref name=":0" />
== AudioSlides == The ''Journal of Anthropological Archaeology'' offers the [http://www.elsevier.com/books-and-journals/content-innovation/audioslides AudioSlides] service free of charge to the journal's contributors and readers. The service offers authors the opportunity to verbally explain their work. Audio files may be embedded in personal websites and are attached to their respective articles.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Elsevier Editorial SystemTM|url = http://ees.elsevier.com/yjaar/|website = ees.elsevier.com|accessdate = 2015-09-01}}</ref>
== Interactive Maps == The ''Journal of Anthropological Archaeology'' also offers interactive maps that allow readers to view geospatial data provided by the author through Google Maps. The interactive maps are KML or KMZ files uploaded by the author. These maps allow the author to pinpoint specific research locations and create annotations for those locations. They are also beneficial to readers who want to understand the author's geographical data and interact with it in an interesting way.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Interactive Maps|url = http://www.elsevier.com/books-and-journals/content-innovation/interactive-maps|website = www.elsevier.com|accessdate = 2015-09-08|last = Elsevier}}</ref>

'''Joyce Marcus''' is a Latin American [[archaeologist]] and professor in the Department of [[Anthropology]], [[Anthropology|College of Literature, Science, and the Arts]] at the [[University of Michigan|University of Michigan, Ann Arbor]]. She also holds the position of Curator of Latin American Archaeology, University of Michigan Museum of Anthropological Archaeology.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Faculty {{!}} Anthropology {{!}} University of Michigan|url = https://www.lsa.umich.edu/anthro/people/faculty/ci.marcusjoyce_ci.detail|website = www.lsa.umich.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-28}}</ref> Marcus has published extensively in the field of [[archaeology of the Americas|Latin American archaeological research]]. Her focus has been primarily on the [[Zapotec civilization|Zapotec]], [[Maya civilization|Maya]], and coastal [[Andean states|Andean]] civilizations of Central and South America.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = American Women of Science Since 1900. Vol.2.|last = Wayne|first = Tiffany K.|publisher = ABC-CLIO, LLC|year = 2011|isbn = 9781598841596|location = Santa Barbara, CA|pages = 654–655}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Joyce Marcus|url = http://www.nasonline.org/member-directory/members/891381.html?referrer=https://www.google.com/|website = www.nasonline.org|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> Much of her fieldwork has been concentrated in the [[Valley of Oaxaca|Valley of Oaxaca, Mexico]]. She is known for her "Dynamic model", four-tiered hierarchy, and her use of interdisciplinary study.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Review: Zapotec Civilization: How Urban Society Evolved in Mexico’s Oaxaca Valley|last = Kowalewski|first = Stephen|date = 1996|journal = Antiquity|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |issue = 70|volume = 270|pages = 1002}}</ref>
== Biography == Joyce Marcus was born in California. She credits receiving a copy of ''An Introduction to the Study of the Maya Hieroglyphs'' by [[Sylvanus Morley|S.G. Morley]] from [[Robert Heizer|Dr. Robert F. Heizer]] in 1969 after a field season in Lovelock, Nevada with influencing her to get into the field of hieroglyphics.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title = Emblem and State in the Classic Maya Lowlands: An Epigraphic Approach to Territorial Organization|last = Marcus|first = Joyce|publisher = Dumbarton Oaks|year = 1976|isbn = 978-0884020660|location = Washington, DC|pages = }}</ref>
She received her B.A. from the [[University of California, Berkeley]] in 1969, and went on to receive her M.A. in 1971 and her Ph.D in 1974, both from [[Harvard University]].<ref name=":1" /> She did her dissertation under her mentor, [[Tatiana Proskouriakoff]], and [[Gordon Willey|Gordon R. Willey]], [[Jerry Sabloff|Jeremy A. Sabloff]], and [[Evon Z. Vogt]].<ref name=":4" /> Her book, ''Emblem and State in the Classic Maya Lowlands: An Epigraphic Approach to Territorial Organization'', is the published version of her dissertation.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Review: Emblem and State in the Classic Maya Lowlands: An Epigraphic Approach to Territorial Organization|last = Cohodas|first = Marvin|date = 1978|journal = American Indian Quarterly|doi = 10.2307/1183968|pmid = |access-date = |issue = 1|volume = 4|pages = 62–65}}</ref>
Marcus has spent her entire teaching career at the University of Michigan, from 1973 to the present, though she has been invited to guest lecture all over the world.<ref name=":1" /> She became a curator for Latin American Archaeology for the University of Michigan Museum of Anthropology in 1978.<ref name=":1" /> She has also consulted for the American Museum of Natural History in New York, the University Museum at the University of Pennsylvania, the Cotson Institute of Archaeology at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Peabody Museum at Harvard University.<ref name=":1" />
In 1997 Marcus was elected to [[National Academy of Sciences|the National Academy of Sciences]], and in 2005 she became the first archaeologist elected to the council.<ref name=":1" /> In 2005 the University of Michigan awarded her the Robert L. Carneiro Distinguished University Professor of Social Evolution.<ref name=":0" /> Marcus is also a fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]], [[American Philosophical Society]], and Institute of Andean Studies.<ref name=":1" /> She is a member of the [[American Anthropological Association]], the [[Society for American Archaeology]], the American Society for Ethnohistory, the Midwest Andeanist Society, and the Midwest Mesoamerican Society.<ref name=":1" />
She has received funding from [[National Endowment for the Humanities|the National Endowment for the Humanities]], the [[Ford Foundation]], the Bowditch Fund at Harvard University, [[Dumbarton Oaks]], the American Association for University Women, the [[National Science Foundation]], and the University of Michigan.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title = Mesoamerican Writing Systems: Propaganda, Myth, and History in Four Ancient Civilizations|last = Marcus|first = Joyce|publisher = Princeton University Press|year = 1992|isbn = 978-0691094748|location = Princeton, New Jersey|pages = xxi-xxii}}</ref>
William J. Folan invited her to record the Maya monuments at [[Calakmul Municipality|Calakmul, Campech]] and surrounding areas in 1983-1984.<ref name=":5" /> She has done research at Dumbarton Oaks Center for Pre-Columbian Studies in Washington, DC.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Ancient City Planning on the Yucatan Peninsula|last = |first = |date = 1973|journal = Science News|doi = 10.2307/3957903|pmid = |access-date = |issue = 22|volume = 103|pages = 354}}</ref> Marcus often works and publishes with her husband [[Kent V. Flannery]].<ref name=":3" /> Marcus and Flannery directed the Valley of Oaxaca Human Ecology Project with the University of Michigan, a long-term project designed by Flannery.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = The Last Quarter Century of Archaeological Research in the Central Valleys of Oaxaca|last = Feinman|first = Gary M.|date = 2007|journal = Mexicon|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 29|pages = 3–15}}</ref>
== Awards<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = joyce marcus {{!}} University of Michigan - Academia.edu|url = https://umich.academia.edu/joycemarcus|website = umich.academia.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-29}}</ref> == * 1979 The Henry Russel Award for Scholarly research from the University of Michigan * 1992 Honorable mention for outstanding book in the social sciences and humanities by the Latin American Studies Association for her book ''Mesoamerican Writing Systems: Propaganda, Myth, and history in four Ancient Civilizations'' * 1995 Literature, Science, and Arts Excellence in Research Award from the University of Michigan * 1998-2005 Elman R Service Professor of Cultural evolution from the University of Michigan * 2005 Robert L. Carneiro Distinguished University Professor of Social Evolution from the University of Michigan * 2001 The Premio Caniem en el Arte Editorial award in Mexico for "La Civilización Zapoteca: Como Evolucionó La Sociedad Urbana en el Valle de Oaxaca" written with Kent Flannery * 2003 Special recognition, Universidad Autónoma de Campeche * 2007 Distinguished Faculty Achievement Award, the University of Michigan, Mentor Recognition Award, the University of California, San Diego * 2008 The Cotson Book prize in archaeology for ''Excavations at Cerro Azul, Peru: The Architecture and Pottery'' * 2014 Corresponding fellow of the [[Academia Mexicana de la Historia]].

'''''Jure matris''''' ('''''iure matris''''') is a [[Latin]] phrase meaning "by right of his mother" or "in right of his mother".
It is commonly encountered in the law of [[inheritance]] when a noble title or other right passes from mother to son. It is also used in the context of monarchy in cases where a woman holds a title in her own right but grants exercise of the power to her son. In many cultures it was common for the husband of a titled woman to [[Jure uxoris|exercise power on her behalf]], and sometimes after his death she allowed their son and heir the same privilege during her lifetime.
==Notable ''jure matris'' rulers== * [[Baldwin III of Jerusalem]] was ''jure matris'' [[List of Kings of Jerusalem|King of Jerusalem]] from 1143 to 1153 through his mother [[Melisende of Jerusalem|Melisende]].<ref>*{{cite book |chapter=Women in the Crusader States: The Queens of Jerusalem |title=Medieval Women |last=Hamilton |first=Bernard |authorlink= |editor=Baker, Derek |year=1978 |publisher=Ecclesiastical History Society |location=Oxford |isbn=0-631-19260-3 |pages= |url= }}</ref> * [[Richard I of England|Richard the Lionheart]] and his brother [[John, King of England|John]] were ''jure matris'' [[Duke of Aquitaine|Dukes of Aquitaine]] from 1189 to 1199 and 1199 to 1204 respectively through their mother [[Eleanor of Aquitaine|Eleanor]], who was Duchess of Aquitaine in her own right. * [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]], was [[List of Castilian monarchs|King of Castile]] through his mother [[Joanna of Castile|Joanna]] from 1516 to 1555. * [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor]], was [[Archduke of Austria]] from 1765 to 1780 through his mother [[Maria Theresa]].
==See also== * ''[[Jure uxoris]]'' * [[List of Latin phrases]] * [[List of queens regnant]] * [[Primogeniture]] * ''[[Suo jure]]''

{{History of Japan |image=Shoso-in.jpg |caption=[[Shōsōin]]}} {{nihongo|'''Jōō'''|貞応|}}, also romanized as '''Jō-ō,''' was a [[Japanese era name]] (年号, ''nengō'', lit. year name) after ''[[Jokyu|Jōkyū]]'' and before ''[[Gennin]].'' This period spanned the years from April 1222 to November 1224.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "''Jō-ō''" in [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA432&dq= ''Japan encyclopedia'', p. 432;] n.b., Louis-Frédéric is pseudonym of Louis-Frédéric Nussbaum, ''see'' [https://archive.is/20120524174828/http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 Deutsche Nationalbibliothek Authority File]. The reigning emperor was [[Emperor Go-Horikawa|Go-Horikawa]]''-tennō''.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). [https://books.google.com/books?id=18oNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PP9&dq=nipon+o+dai+itsi+ran#PRA1-PA238,M1 ''Annales des empereurs du Japon'', pp. 238]-241; Brown, Delmer ''et al.'' (1979). ''Gukanshō'', pp. 341-343; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). ''Jinnō Shōtōki.'' pp. 226-227. ==Change of era== * '''1222''' {{nihongo|''Jōō gannen''|貞応元年}}: The era name was changed to ''Jōō'' (meaning "Righteous Answer") to mark an event or a number of events. The previous era ended and a new one commenced in ''Jōkyū'', on the 13th day of the 4th month of 1222.Brown, p. 346. ==Events of the ''Jōō'' era== * '''1222''' (''Jōō 2''): Regulations established concerning salaries for ''[[Jito|Jitō]]'' * '''July 19, 1223''' (''Jōō 2, 20th day of the 6th month''): The buildings of the [[Asama Shrine]] at the base of [[Mount Fuji]] in [[Suruga province]] were re-built by [[Hōjō Tokimasa]].Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. '''Lisa Sousa''' (born 1962)<ref>{{cite LAF|id=n98-53975}}</ref> is an American academic historian active in the field of [[Latin American studies]]. A specialist in the [[Spanish conquest of the Americas|colonial-era]] history of [[Latin America]] and of [[Colonial Mexico]] in particular, Sousa is noted for her research, commentary, and translations of colonial [[Mesoamerican literature]] and [[Nahuatl]]-language historical texts. She has also published research on historical and contemporary [[indigenous peoples in Mexico]], the roles of women in indigenous societies and cultural definitions of [[gender]]. {{As of|2009}} Sousa holds a position as [[assistant professor]] in the History Department at [[Occidental College]] in [[Los Angeles, California]].<ref name="Lisa Sousa profile">{{cite web|title=Lisa Sousa [profile |url=http://departments.oxy.edu/history/lsousa/index.htm |work=History Department faculty |publisher=[[Occidental College]] |accessdate=2009-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081009060737/http://departments.oxy.edu/history/lsousa/index.htm |archivedate=2008-10-09 |df= }}</ref>
==Studies and career== Lisa Sousa was born 1962 in [[Sebastopol, California]].<ref>{{cite LAF|id=n98-53975|text=Birthplace}}</ref> She attended the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA) as an undergraduate, completing a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[Latin American studies]] in 1990. Her postgraduate studies in Latin American history were also undertaken at UCLA, where her research focused on the history and experience of women and indigenous cultures in colonial-era [[Mexico]].
Sousa first completed her [[Master of Arts|Master's degree]] in 1992 before entering the doctorate studies program, and was awarded her [[PhD]] in 1998.<ref name="Curriculum Vitae">{{cite web|title=Curriculum Vitae |url=http://departments.oxy.edu/history/profs/sousa/cv.htm |publisher=Occidental College |accessdate=2009-06-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101116122352/http://departments.oxy.edu/history/profs/sousa/cv.htm |archivedate=2010-11-16 |df= }}</ref> Her doctoral [[dissertation]], "Women in Native Societies and Cultures of Colonial Mexico", won UCLA's Mary Wollstonecraft Dissertation Award for the best thesis in [[Women's studies]].<ref name="Lisa Sousa profile"/>
As her PhD was being completed, Sousa obtained a position as adjunct professor at Occidental College in the 1997–98 academic year. After a brief term as a [[visiting lecturer]] at UCLA, Sousa took up an [[assistant professor]]ship at Occidental, from 1998 onwards. In addition to her continuing research and publications in the field, Sousa teaches a number of related courses in [[History of Latin America|Latin American history]], [[Mesoamerican literature]] and [[gender studies]], and also provides instruction in learning Nahuatl.<ref name="Curriculum Vitae"/>
==Research== During the course of her studies at UCLA Sousa obtained a proficiency in [[Classical Nahuatl]], an indigenous language of the [[Mexican Plateau|central Mexican altiplano]] and ''[[lingua franca]]'' of the [[Aztec Empire]] at the time of the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|Spanish conquest]] in the 16th century.
While studying at UCLA in the 1990s Sousa researched and published papers on a themes relating to women and gender among indigenous cultures in Mexico. Themes analysed by Sousa include rationalisation of and attitudes to [[violence against women]], the representation and participation of women in crime and colonial-era rebellion, and [[Slavery in the Spanish New World colonies|slavery of indigenous groups in the New World]]. Her publications and seminars also explore the nature of [[gender roles in Mesoamerica|gender roles in Mesoamerican cultures]], particularly among [[Nahua peoples|Nahua]], [[Mixtec peoples|Mixtec]] and [[Zapotec peoples]] of the pre- and post-conquest eras.<ref name="Curriculum Vitae"/>
In 1998 as her PhD was being completed, Sousa co-edited and translated an English-language edition of the ''[[Huei tlamahuiçoltica]]'', a 17th-century Nahuatl-language manuscript that is central to the claims of the [[Our Lady of Guadalupe|Guadalupan apparition]] to [[Juan Diego]]. The book, ''The Story of Guadalupe: Luis Laso de la Vega's Huei tlamahuiçoltica of 1649'', jointly published by [[Stanford University Press]] and UCLA's Latin American Center, also contains analysis of and translated excerpts from the 1648 document, ''Imagen de la Virgen María, Madre de Dios de Guadalupe'' by [[Miguel Sánchez]]. Together with her collaborators [[Stafford Poole]] and [[James Lockhart (historian)|James Lockhart]], Sousa affirms that [[Luis Laso de la Vega]] was indeed the principal author of the ''Huei tlamahuiçoltica'',<ref>Sousa ''et al.'' 1998, pp.43–47</ref> and that portions of the work bear affinities with Sánchez's document.<ref>Summarised in Sousa ''et al.'' 1998, pp.5–17</ref> They regard Sánchez's ''Imagen de la Virgen María'' as the earliest known written account of the Guadalupan apparition,<ref>Sousa ''et al.'' 1998, pp.1–2</ref> and that consequently these two mid-17th-century texts are the principal origins of the apparition story, and not any earlier source or tradition contemporaneous with the events purported to have taken place more than a century before those documents were written.<ref>Sousa ''et al.'' 1998, p.1</ref>
IN 2004, Sousa and UCLA professor [[Kevin Terraciano]] were presented with the Robert F. Heizer Article Award by the [[American Society for Ethnohistory]], for their co-authored paper "The 'Original Conquest' of Oaxaca: Nahua and Mixtec Accounts of the Spanish Conquest", published the preceding year in the journal ''[[Ethnohistory (journal)|Ethnohistory]].''<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert F. Heizer Article Award |url=http://www.ethnohistory.org/sections/awards_prizes/robert_f_heizer.html |work=Awards and Prizes |publisher=[[American Society for Ethnohistory]] |accessdate=2009-06-01}}</ref>
In 2005 Sousa co-edited and with [[Matthew Restall]] and Terraciano a volume of translated colonial-era Nahuatl-, [[Mayan languages|Mayan]]- and [[Mixtec language|Mixtec-language]] primary source texts, under the title ''Mesoamerican Voices: Native-Language Writings from Colonial Mexico and Guatemala''.<ref>Restall ''et al.'' 2005</ref>

<!--see note on talk page about why this list exists--> This is a '''list of types of funerary monument''', a physical structure that commemorates a deceased person or a group, in the latter case usually those whose deaths occurred at the same time or in similar circumstances. The funerary monument differs from a tomb or cemetery in that while it may or may not contain the body of the deceased, its primary purpose is not simply to house the remains, but to serve as a visible reminder of the dead for the living. It often features inscriptions ([[epitaph]]s) or [[funerary art]].
* [[Headstone]] *[[Eternal flame]] *[[Cenotaph]] * [[Mortuary enclosure]] * [[Mortuary house]] *[[Pillar tomb]] * [[Heroon]] *[[Sarcophagus]] *[[Recumbent effigy]] *[[Rock-cut tombs in ancient Israel]] *[[Stone ship]] * [[Church monuments]] ** [[English church monuments]] * [[Memorial cross]] * [[War memorial]] * [[Scottish gravestones]] * [[Roadside memorial]]

'''Michael G. Vann''' (born June 19, 1967) is an American historian who serves as Associate Professor of History at [[California State University, Sacramento]]. He specializes in the history of the [[French colonial empire]]. Vann holds a [http://history.ucsc.edu/graduate/alumni/index.html Ph.D. in History] from the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]], where he was a student of [[Tyler Stovall]] and [[Edmund Burke III]]. His dissertation was on the history of white supremacy in French colonial [[Hanoi]]. He is a graduate of '[[Iolani School]] in [[Honolulu|Honolulu, Hawai'i]], his home town.
==Accomplishments== Vann has won two [[Fulbright]] awards, one for doctoral research in France, 1995-1996, and a Senior Scholar award to Indonesia, 2012-2013. In Indonesia he was a visiting scholar for the History and American Studies departments at [[Universitas Gadjah Mada]] in [[Yogyakarta]], Java.
He was President of the [http://www.frenchcolonial.org French Colonial Historical Society] from 2008 to 2010. He is a member of a post-1999 wave of historians who adopted a new critical approach to this history of France and its colonial empire.
Vann has published two books: ''The Colonial Good Life: André Joyeux's Vision of French Indochina''<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael G. Vann |url=https://www.amazon.com/The-Colonial-Good-Life-Commentary/dp/9744801425 |title=The Colonial Good Life: Commentary on Andre Joyeux's Vision of French Indochina (English and French Edition): Michael G. Vann, Joel Montague, Andre Joyeux: 9789744801425: Amazon.com: Books |publisher=Amazon.com |date=2008-12-01 |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref> and ''20th Century Voices: Selected Readings in World History.''<ref>{{cite book|last=Vann|first=Michael|title=Twentieth Century Voices: Selected Readings in World History (Revised Edition)|year=2013|isbn=978-1-62131-232-1|url=https://titles.cognella.com/catalog/product/view/id/26765/s/twentieth-century-voices-9781621312321/category/3820/}}</ref> Vann was featured on public radio's Freakonomics, speaking about how his research on rat hunting in colonial Hanoi related to the economic concept "[[perverse incentive]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Dubner|first=Stephen|title=The Cobra Effect: A New Freakonomics Radio Podcast|url=http://freakonomics.com/2012/10/11/the-cobra-effect-a-new-freakonomics-radio-podcast/|accessdate=29 December 2013}}</ref> He was interviewed about French colonialism on KUSP's 7th Avenue Project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://7thavenueproject.com/post/31761023474/mike-vann-colonialism |title=Show for Sept. 9, 2012. Our Man in Hanoi:... - The 7th Avenue Project: Thinking Persons' Radio |publisher=The 7th Avenue Project |date=2012-09-09 |accessdate=2014-03-02}}</ref>
He has also published articles on Indonesian history and politics, including the [[Cebongan Prison raid]], 2013,<ref>{{cite web|last=Vann|first=Michael|title=Shadow Puppets and Special Forces: Indonesia’s Fragile Democracy|url=http://thediplomat.com/2013/06/shadow-puppets-and-special-forces-indonesias-fragile-democracy/?allpages=yes|publisher=The Dipolmat|accessdate=29 December 2013}}</ref> and [[Lawang Sewu]], a Dutch era haunted house in [[Semarang]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Vann|first=Michael|title=Haunted house, haunted history|url=http://www.insideindonesia.org/current-edition/haunted-house-haunted-history|publisher=Inside Indonesia|accessdate=29 December 2013}}</ref>
==Athletic achievements==
Hailing from [[Oahu|O'ahu, Hawai'i]], Vann is an accomplished surfer who frequently travels to Indonesia. He holds a black belt in [[Brazilian Jiu Jitsu]]. He has taught Brazilian Jiu Jitsu at [http://www.kaijinmma.com Kaijin MMA] in [[Santa Cruz, California]].

{{English phonology topics}} This article describes those aspects of the [[phonological history of the English language]] which concern [[consonant]]s. ==Consonant clusters== {{Main article|Phonological history of English consonant clusters}} ===H-cluster reductions=== * [[English wh|Reduction of /hw/]] – to /h/ in a few words (such as ''who''), but usually to {{IPA|/w/}}, for the great majority of English speakers (so that ''whine'' comes to be pronounced the same as ''wine''). * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#HL|Reduction of /hl/, /hr/ and /hn/]], with the loss of the initial {{IPA|/h/}} in Middle English. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Reduction of /hj/|Reduction of /hj/]] to /j/ in a few American and Irish dialects (so that ''hew'' is pronounced like ''yew''). ===Y-cluster reductions=== * [[Yod-dropping]] – the [[elision]] of {{IPA|/j/}} in certain clusters, depending on dialect (for example, [[Received Pronunciation|RP]] has /j/ in ''new'', while [[General American]] and [[Cockney]] do not). * [[Yod-coalescence]], whereby the clusters {{IPA|/dj/}}, {{IPA|/tj/}}, {{IPA|/sj/}} and {{IPA|/zj/}} become {{IPA|[dʒ]}}, {{IPA|[tʃ]}}, {{IPA|[ʃ]}} and {{IPA|[ʒ]}} respectively (for example, ''education'' is often pronounced as if it began "edge"). ===Other initial cluster reductions=== * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#wr|Reduction of /wr/]] to /r/, in words like ''wrap'', around the 17th century (there was also a reduction of /wl/ to /l/ in Middle English). * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Reduction of /kn/|Reduction of /kn/]] and [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Reduction of /ɡn/|/ɡn/]] to /n/, in words like ''knot'' and ''gnome'', around the 17th century. * [[S-cluster reduction]], in some types of [[Caribbean English]], where for example ''spit'' is pronounced ''pit''. ===Final cluster reductions=== * [[NG-coalescence]] – reduction of the final cluster {{IPA|[ŋɡ]}} to {{IPA|[ŋ]}}, in words like ''hang'', which has occurred in all but a few English dialects. * [[G-dropping]] – reduction of the final cluster {{IPA|[ŋɡ]}} to {{IPA|[n]}} in weak syllables, principally in the verb ending ''[[-ing]]'', which has occurred in many English dialects, although not in the modern standard varieties. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#mb|Reduction of /mb/ and /mn/]] to {{IPA|/m/}}, in later Middle English, affecting words like ''lamb'' and ''column''. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Generalized final cluster reduction|Generalized final cluster reduction]] in [[African American Vernacular English]] (AAVE) and [[Caribbean English]], where for example ''desk'' and ''hand'' may be pronounced "dess" and "han". ===Other changes involving clusters=== * [[C#Later use|Reduction of /ts/ to /s/]] – a Middle English reduction that produced the modern sound of [[soft C|soft {{vr|c}}]]. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Medial cluster reductions|Medial cluster reduction]] – elision of certain stops in medial clusters, such as the /t/ in ''postman''. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Consonant insertions|Insertion (epenthesis) of stops]] after nasals in certain clusters, for example making ''prince'' sound like ''prints'', and ''dreamt'' rhyme with ''attempt''. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Assimilation|Assimilation]] of certain consonants in clusters, especially nasals. * [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Glottalization|Glottalization and pre-glottalization]] (insertion of a [[glottal stop]] in place of or before a /t/ or other stop) in certain environments, depending on dialect. * Certain other changes occurring in AAVE, including [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#S-cluster metathesis|S-cluster metathesis]] (as with the use of "aks" for ''ask'' – an alternation which also has a long history in general forms of English), the [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Merger of /str/ and /skr/|merger of /str/ and /skr/]], and [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Yod-rhotacization|yod-rhotacization]] (where ''beautiful'' is pronounced "brootiful"). ==Stops== ===Aspiration=== The [[voiceless stop]]s /p/, /t/, /k/ are typically [[aspirated consonant|aspirated]] when they begin a stressed syllable, becoming {{IPA|[pʰ], [tʰ], [kʰ]}}, as described under [[English phonology#Obstruents|English phonology (obstruents)]]. There is some regional variation in the degree of aspiration, and in some Scottish and northern English accents aspiration does not occur at all.Wells (1982), p. 74. In certain accents, such as [[Geordie]] (among younger women) and in some speakers of [[Hiberno-English|Dublin English]],{{cite web|title=Glossary|url=https://www.uni-due.de/vcde/VCDE_Glossary.htm#GlossE|accessdate=11 February 2015}} /p/, /t/ and /k/ can be [[preaspiration|preaspirated]] when they come at the end of a word or utterance, becoming {{IPA|[ʰp], [ʰt], [ʰk]}}. ===Flapping=== {{Main article|Flapping}} [[Flapping]], or tapping, is a process whereby /t/ or /d/ is pronounced as the [[alveolar flap]] {{IPA|[ɾ]}} in certain positions, especially between vowels (but also sometimes after other sonorants). It may be perceived as, for example, the pronunciation of ''butter'' as "budder". It occurs especially in [[North American English]] (to varying extents) and in [[Australian English|Australian]] and [[New Zealand English]]. ===Voicing=== Apart from the T-voicing that results from flapping (described above), some dialects feature other instances of [[voiced consonant|voicing]] or [[lenis consonant|lenition]] of the stops /p/, /t/ and /k/. In [[Geordie]], these stops may be fully voiced ([b], [d], [ɡ]) in intervocalic position.{{Harvcoltxt|Watt|Allen|2003|p=268}} In [[Devon]], stops and other [[obstruent]]s may be voiced (or at least lenited) between vowels and when final after a weak vowel, so for example the /k/ and /t/ in ''jacket'' may approach the realizations [ɡ] and [d], making the word sound similar or identical to ''jagged''.Wells (1982), pp. 343–344. ===Glottalization=== Stops, chiefly the voiceless stops, and especially /t/, are frequently [[glottalized]] or pre-glottalized in certain positions; that is, a stop may be replaced with the [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|[ʔ]}}, or else a glottal stop may be inserted before it. These phenomena are strongly dependent on the phonetic environment and on dialect. For details, see [[T-glottalization]], as well as [[English phonology#Obstruents|English phonology (obstruents)]] and [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Glottalization|glottalization in consonant clusters]]. If all final voiceless stops are glottalized, as may occur in some London speech, then sets of words such as ''lick'', ''lit'' and ''lip'' may become homophones, pronounced {{IPA|[lɪʔ]}}.Wells (1982), p. 323. ==Fricatives and affricates== ===H-dropping and H-insertion=== {{main article|H-dropping}} [[H-dropping]]{{Anchor|H dropping}}{{Anchor|H-dropping}} is the omission of initial {{IPA|/h/}} in words like ''house'', ''heat'' and ''hangover''. It is common in many dialects, especially in England, Wales, Australia and Jamaica, but is generally [[social stigma|stigmatized]], and is not a feature of the standard accents. The /h/ is nonetheless frequently dropped in all forms of English in the [[weak and strong forms in English|weak form]]s of [[function word]]s like ''he'', ''him'', ''her'', ''his'', ''had'' and ''have''. The opposite of H-dropping, called H-insertion or H-adding, may arise as a [[hypercorrection]] by typically H-dropping speakers, or as a [[spelling pronunciation]]. ===Loss of velar and palatal fricatives=== The voiceless velar and palatal fricative sounds [x] and [ç], considered to be [[allophone]]s of /h/, and reflected by the {{angbr|gh}} in the spelling of words such as ''night'', ''taught'' and ''weight'', were lost in later Middle English or in Early Modern English. Their loss was accompanied by certain changes in the previous vowels. In some cases [x] became /f/, as in ''laugh''. A /x/ is still heard in words of the above type in certain Scots and northern English traditional dialect speech. A /x/ is more commonly heard – especially in the [[Celtic nations|Celtic countries]], but also for many speakers elsewhere – in the word ''loch'' and in certain proper names such as ''[[Buchan]]''. For details of the above phenomena, see [[Middle English phonology#H-loss|H-loss (Middle English)]]. See also the [[Middle English phonology#gu|vocalization of the voiced velar fricative {{IPA|[ɣ]}}]]. ===Voiced/voiceless splits=== The Old English fricatives {{IPA|/f, θ, s/}} had voiceless and voiced allophones, the voiced forms occurring in certain environments, such as between vowels. In Early Middle English, partly due to borrowings from French, these split into separate phonemes: {{IPA|/f, v, θ, ð, s, z/}}. See [[Middle English phonology#Voiced fricatives|Middle English phonology – Voiced fricatives]]. Also in the Middle English period, the voiced affricate {{IPA|/dʒ/}} took on phonemic status (in Old English it is considered to have been an allophone of /j/). It occurred in Middle English not only in words like ''brigge'' ("bridge"), in which it had been present in Old English, but also in French loans such as ''juge'' ("judge") and ''general''. After the Middle English period, a fourth voiced fricative, {{IPA|/ʒ/}}, developed as a phoneme (alongside the voiceless {{IPA|/ʃ/}}). This arose from [[yod-coalescence]] ({{IPA|/zj/→/ʒ/}}) in words like ''measure'', and from late French loans such as ''rouge'' and ''beige''.Prins, A.A., ''A History of English Phonemes'', Leiden University Press 1972, p. 222. ===Dental fricatives=== {{main article|Pronunciation of English ⟨th⟩}} As noted above, the Old English phoneme {{IPA|/θ/}} split into two phonemes in early Middle English: a [[voiceless dental fricative]] {{IPA|/θ/}} and a [[voiced dental fricative]]{{IPA|/ð/}}. Both continued to be spelt {{angbr|th}}. Certain English accents feature variant pronunciations of these sounds. These include [[Th-fronting|fronting]], where they merge with /f/ and /v/ (found in [[Cockney]] and some other dialects); [[Th-stopping|stopping]], where they approach /t/ and /d/ (as in some Irish speech); [[Th-alveolarization|alveolarization]], where they become {{IPA|/s/ and /z/}} (in some African varieties); and [[Th-debuccalization|debuccalization]], where {{IPA|/θ/}} becomes {{IPA|[h]}} before a vowel (found in some [[Scottish English]]). ===Initial fricative voicing=== [[File:Initial fricative voicing.svg|thumb|The initial consonant in the word ''finger'' in traditional dialects of England.]] Initial fricative voicing is a process that occurs in some traditional accents of the English [[West Country]], where the fricatives {{IPA|/f/}}, {{IPA|/θ/}}, {{IPA|/s/}} and {{IPA|/ʃ/}} are voiced to {{IPA|[v]}}, {{IPA|[ð]}}, {{IPA|[z]}} and {{IPA|[ʒ]}} when they occur at the beginning of a word. (Words beginning {{IPA|/θr/}}, like ''three'', develop /dr/ instead.) In these accents, ''sing'' and ''farm'' are pronounced {{IPA|[zɪŋ]}} and {{IPA|[vɑːɻm]}}. The phenomenon is well known as a [[stereotype|stereotypical]] feature, but is now rare in actual speech.Wells (1982), p. 342. Some such pronunciations have spread from these dialects to become standard usage: the words ''vane'', ''vat'' and ''vixen'' all had initial /f/ in Old English (''fana'', ''fæt'', ''fyxen'').{{OEtymD|V}} A similar phenomenon occurred in both [[German language|German]] and [[Dutch language|Dutch]]. ===Other changes=== * In [[Glasgow]] and some other urban Scottish accents, /s/ is given an [[apico-alveolar]] articulation, which auditorily gives an impression of a [[retraction (phonetics)|retracted]] pronunciation similar to {{IPA|/ʃ/}}.Cole, J., Hualde, J.I., ''Laboratory Phonology 9'', Walter de Gruyter 2007, p. 69. Replacement of /s/ with {{IPA|/ʃ/}} is found in some Asian accents, as depicted by ''[[South Park]]'' character [[Tuong Lu Kim]]'s pronunciation of ''city'' as "shitty". Confusion between {{IPA|/ʃ/}} and {{IPA|/s/}} (or {{IPA|/tʃ/}}) also occurs in some African varieties of English, so ''ship'' may be pronounced like ''sip'' (or ''chip'').Wells (1982), p. 640. In [[Zulu English]], it is reported that {{IPA|/tʃ/}} is sometimes replaced by {{IPA|/ʃ/}}.Wade, R., [https://web.archive.org/web/20080517054614/http://www.und.ac.za/und/ling/archive/wade_ch4.html ''The structural characteristics of Zulu English''], 4.2.3. *The [[labiodental]] fricative /v/ is sometimes merged with the corresponding [[bilabial]] stop /b/. Some speakers of [[Caribbean English]]Wells (1982), p. 568. and [[Mexican American English]] merge {{IPA|/v/}} with {{IPA|/b/}}, making ''ban'' and ''van'' homophones (pronounced as {{IPA|[ban]}}, or as {{IPA|[βan]}} with a [[Voiced bilabial fricative|bilabial fricative]]). The distinction of /v/ from /b/ is one of the last phonological distinctions commonly learnt by English-speaking children generally, and pairs like ''dribble/drivel'' may be pronounced similarly even by adults. *In [[Indian English]], /v/ is often pronounced like /w/, sounded as [w] or as a labiodental approximant {{IPA|[ʋ]}}.Wells (1982), p. 629. Some Indian speakers make various changes in the pronunciation of other fricatives: {{IPA|/z/}} may become {{IPA|[dʒ]}} or {{IPA|[dz]}}; {{IPA|/ʃ/}} may become {{IPA|[s]}} or {{IPA|[sj]}}; {{IPA|/ʒ/}} may become {{IPA|[ʃ]}}, {{IPA|[z]}} or {{IPA|[dʒ]}}, {{IPA|/dʒ/}} may become {{IPA|[z]}} or {{IPA|[dz]}}; {{IPA|/tʃ/}} may become {{IPA|[ts]}}; {{IPA|/f/}} may become a [[voiceless bilabial fricative|bilabial]] {{IPA|[ɸ]}} or an aspirated stop {{IPA|[ph]}}.Wells (1982), pp. 628–629. For {{IPA|/θ/ and /ð/}}, see [[th-stopping|''th''-stopping]]. *For some speakers of [[Mexican American English]], initial {{IPA|/dʒ/}} and {{IPA|/j/}} may be used in place of each other, so ''jet'' may be pronounced as ''yet'' or vice versa.[https://www.uni-due.de/SVE/VARS_Chicano.htm "Chicano English"], Universität Duisburg-Essen. Retrieved 2015-10-02. *In [[South African English|Indian South African English]], the typical realization of the labiodental fricatives {{IPA|/f, v/}} are the approximants {{IPA|[{{IPA link|ʋ̥}}, {{IPA link|ʋ}}]}}.{{Citation|last=Mesthrie|first=Rajend|editor-last=Schneider|editor-first=Edgar W.|editor2-last=Burridge|editor2-first=Kate|editor3-last=Kortmann|editor3-first=Bernd|editor4-last=Mesthrie|editor4-first=Rajend|editor5-last=Upton|editor5-first=Clive|year=2004|title=A handbook of varieties of English|chapter=Indian South African English: phonology|volume=1: Phonology|publisher=Mouton de Gruyter|page=960|isbn=3-11-017532-0}} ==Approximants== ===Insertion and deletion of /j/ and /w/ === In parts of the west and southwest of England, initial /w/ may be dropped in words like ''wool'' and ''woman''; occasionally, though, a /w/ may be inserted before certain vowels, as in "wold" for ''old'' and "bwoiling" for ''boiling''. Similarly, initial /j/ may be lost in words like ''yeast'' and ''yes'' (this has also been reported in parts of eastern England), and may be added in words like ''earth'' (making "yearth").Wakelin, M.F., ''Discovering English Dialects'', Osprey Publishing 1994, p. 27. For the much more widespread deletion of /j/ in consonant clusters, see [[yod-dropping]] (and compare also [[yod-coalescence]] and [[yod-rhotacization]]). For the historical loss of /w/ in such words as ''who'' and ''write'', see [[English wh|pronunciation of ''wh'']] and [[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#wr|reduction of /wr/]]. ===Realizations of /r/=== Old and Middle English /r/ was historically pronounced as an [[alveolar trill]], [r]. At some time between later Middle English and Early Modern English, it changed to an [[alveolar approximant]], {{IPA|[ɹ]}}, in the standard accents. Some Scottish speakers, however, retain the original trilled ("rolled") /r/.Pfenninger, S.E. et al., ''Contact, Variation, and Change in the History of English'', John Benjamins 2014, p. 98. Another possible realization of /r/ is the [[alveolar tap]], {{IPA|[ɾ]}}. This is common (alongside {{IPA|[ɹ]}}) in Scotland, and is also found in certain other accents, chiefly in positions between vowels or between a consonant and a vowel – this occurs, for example, in some [[Liverpool English]] and in some upper-class [[Received Pronunciation|RP]]Wells (1982), pp. 282, 372, 411. (this should not be confused with the [[Flapping|tap pronunciation of /t/ and /d/]], found especially in North America). In most [[General American]], /r/ is {{IPA|[ɹ]}} before a vowel, but when not followed by a vowel is generally realized as an [[r-colored vowel]], [ɚ], or as r-coloring on the preceding vowel. In many accents of English, including RP, /r/ is lost altogether when not followed by a vowel – for this, see [[rhoticity in English]] (and for related phenomena, [[linking and intrusive R]]). For vowel changes before /r/, see [[English-language vowel changes before historic /r/]]. A uvular realization of /r/, the "[[Northumbrian burr]]", is used by some speakers in the far north of England. A relatively recent innovation in the southeast of England, possibly originating from [[Cockney]], is the use of a [[labiodental approximant]], {{IPA|[ʋ]}}, for /r/. To some listeners this can sound like a {{IPA|/w/}}. ===Developments involving /l/ === {{see also|English-language vowel changes before historic /l/}} [[Velarization]] of /l/ in positions where there is no vowel following, producing a [[dark l|"dark L"]], is a phenomenon that goes back to Old English times.Theyskens, L., Taeldeman, J., ''Recent Advances in Phonological Theory'', Communication & Cognition 1979, p. 110. Today there is much variation between dialects as regards the degree and distribution of this velarization; see [[English phonology#Sonorants|English phonology (sonorants)]]. In [[Early Modern English]], in many words in which a dark /l/ followed the vowel {{IPA|/a/}} or {{IPA|/o/}}, the /l/ either disappeared or underwent [[L-vocalization|vocalization]], usually with some kind of [[diphthong]]ization or [[compensatory lengthening]] of the preceding vowel. This affected: * Words with final /al/ and /ol/, which underwent partial L-vocalization, with the insertion of {{IPA|[ʊ]}} between the vowel and the /l/. The resulting diphthongs developed respectively into modern {{IPA|/ɔː/}} in words like ''all'', ''ball'', ''call'', and into the {{sc2|GOAT}} vowel in words like ''poll'', ''scroll'' and ''control''. Some words of more recent origin did not undergo these changes, such as ''pal'', ''doll'' and ''alcohol''; the word ''shall'' is also unaffected. * Words with /al/ and /ol/ followed by a [[coronal consonant]], which followed the same pattern as those above, although here in modern RP the {{IPA|/ɔː/}} of the first set is mostly replaced by a short {{IPA|/ɒ/}}, as in words like ''salt'', ''halt'', ''falter'', ''bald'', ''false'', ''Walsh''. Words in the second set, having the {{sc2|GOAT}} vowel, include ''old'', ''cold'' and ''bolt'' (though some RP speakers also have {{IPA|/ɒ/}} in words like ''bolt''). The word ''solder'' has a variety of pronunciations; in North America the /l/ is often dropped. * Words with /alk/ and /olk/, which again followed the same pattern, but also dropped the /l/, so that words like ''chalk'', ''talk'' and ''walk'' now have {{IPA|/ɔːk/}}, while ''folk'' and ''yolk'' rhyme with ''smoke''. * Words with /alf/ or /alv/ (''calf'', ''half'', ''halve''), which simply lost the /l/ (the vowel of these is now {{IPA|/æ/}} in General American and {{IPA|/ɑː/}} in RP, by {{sc2|BATH}}-broadening). The word ''salve'' is often pronounced with the /l/; the name ''[[Ralph (name)|Ralph]]'' may be {{IPA|/rælf/}}, {{IPA|/rɑːlf/}}, {{IPA|/rɑːf/}} or {{IPA|/reɪf/}}. Words like ''solve'' were not affected, although ''golf'' dropped the {{IPA|/l/}} in some British accents. * Words with /alm/ and /olm/, which lost the /l/ and lengthened the vowel (the lengthened {{IPA|[oː]}} later becoming diphthongized in the [[toe–tow merger]]). Words like ''alms'', ''balm'', ''calm'', ''Chalmers'', ''qualm'', ''palm'' and ''psalm'' now generally have {{IPA|/ɑː/}} in the standard accents, while ''holm'' and ''Holmes'' are [[homophone]]s of ''home(s)''. Some accents (including many of [[American English]]) have reintroduced the {{IPA|/l/}} in these words as a [[spelling pronunciation]]. The word ''salmon'' generally retains a short vowel despite the loss of /l/. * A few words with /alb/ or /olb/, such as ''[[Alban (disambiguation)|Alban]]'' and ''[[Albany (disambiguation)|Albany]]'', which have developed to {{IPA|/ɔːl/}} (though ''[[Albania]]'' usually has {{IPA|/æl/}}), and ''[[Holborn]]'', which has the {{sc2|GOAT}} vowel and no /l/. Words like ''scalp'' and ''[[Alps]]'' are unaffected. As noted under some of the points above, /l/ may be reintroduced in some of the words from which it has been lost, as a spelling pronunciation. This happens sometimes in [[Irish English]], where for example ''[[Dundalk]]'' may be pronounced {{IPA|/dʌndɔːlk/}} (in standard English the {{angbr|l}} is silent). The /l/ has also been lost in the words [[English modal verbs#Etymology|''would'' and ''should'']]. The word ''could'' was never pronounced with /l/; its spelling results from analogy with the former words. Modern [[L-vocalization]] (the replacement of "dark" /l/ with a non-syllabic vowel sound, usually similar to [ʊ] or [o]) is a feature of certain accents, particularly in [[Cockney|London English]] and in near-RP speech that has been influenced by it ("[[Estuary English]]"), in some [[New York English|New York speech]], in the [[Southern American English|American South]] and [[African American Vernacular English]] (AAVE), and according to some reports in [[New Zealand English]].Wells (1982), pp. 295, 313–317, 517, 551, 557, 609. Also in [[AAVE]] and some southern American accents, L-dropping may occur when the {{IPA|/l/}} sound comes after a vowel and before a [[labial consonant]] in the same syllable, causing pronunciations like {{IPA|/hɛp/}} for ''help'' and {{IPA|/sɛf/}} for ''self''.[http://www.rehabmed.ualberta.ca/spa/phonology/features.htm Phonological Features of African American Vernacular English] In some accents around [[Bristol]], "intrusive L" is found, where an /l/ is inserted at the end of words ending in [[schwa]], like ''comma'' and ''idea''. This is now somewhat [[social stigma|stigmatized]], but far from rare. The name ''Bristol'' itself was formerly ''Bristow''.Wells (1982), pp. 344–345. In some modern English accents, significant ''pre-L breaking'' occurs when /l/ follows certain vowels ({{IPA|/iː/}}, {{IPA|/uː/}}, and diphthongs ending {{IPA|[ɪ]}} or {{IPA|[ʊ]}}). Here the vowel develops a centering offglide (an additional [[schwa]]) before the /l/. This may cause ''reel'' to be pronounced like ''real'', and ''tile'', ''boil'' and ''fowl'' to rhyme with ''dial'', ''royal'' and ''vowel''. [[John C. Wells|Wells]] considers this breaking to be a feature of [[midwest]]ern General American, as well as [[New York English]].Wells (1982), pp. 487, 505. Similar pre-L schwa-insertion may also occur after {{IPA|/r/}} (in [[rhotic consonant|rhotic]] accents), leading to pronunciations like {{IPA|[ˈwɜɹəld]}} for ''world''. ==Sound changes involving final consonants== ===Final obstruent devoicing=== Final obstruent devoicing is the full devoicing of final obstruents that occurs for some [[AAVE]] speakers in Detroit where obstruents are devoiced at the end of a word. The preceding length of the vowel is maintained when the final obstruents are devoiced in AAVE, hence the pronunciations {{IPA|[bɪːk]}} and {{IPA|[bæːt]}} for "big" and "bad". Most varieties of [[English language|English]] don't have full devoicing of final voiced obstruents. Nevertheless, voiced obstruents are partially devoiced in final position in English, especially when phrase-final or when followed by a voiceless consonant (for example, ''bad cat'' {{IPA|[bæd̥ kʰæt]}}). The most salient distinction between ''bad'' and ''bat'' is not the voicing of the final consonant but rather the duration of the vowel and possible [[glottalization]] of final {{IPA|[t]}}: ''bad'' is pronounced {{IPA|[bæːd̥]}} while ''bat'' is {{IPA|[bæ(ʔ)t]}}. ===Final consonant deletion=== Final consonant deletion is the nonstandard deletion of single consonants in syllable-final position occurring for some [[AAVE]] speakers resulting in pronunciations like: * bad - {{IPA|[bæː]}} * con - {{IPA|[kɑ̃]}} * foot - {{IPA|[fʊ]}} * five - {{IPA|[faɪ]}} * good - {{IPA|[ɡʊː]}} When final [[nasal consonants]] are deleted, nasality is maintained on the preceding vowel. When voiced [[stop consonant|stop]]s are deleted, length of the preceding vowel is maintained. Consonants remaining from [[English consonant-cluster reductions#Final consonant-cluster reduction|reduced final clusters]] may be eligible for deletion. The deletion occurs especially if the final consonant is a nasal or a stop. Final-consonant deletion is much less frequent than the more common [[English consonant-cluster reductions#Final consonant-cluster reduction|final-cluster reduction]]. Consonants can also be deleted at the end of a morpheme boundary, leading to pronunciations like {{IPA|[kɪːz]}} for ''kids''. ==Other changes== ==={{IPA|/t–r/}} merger=== In [[Cardiff English]], the {{IPA|/t–r/}} contrast may be reduced before {{IPA|/ə/}} and unstressed {{IPA|/ɪ/}}. Phonetically, the merged sound is either an alveolar tap, or a postalveolar approximant. This merger makes e.g. ''starting'' {{IPA|/ˈstaːtɪŋ/}} and ''starring'' {{IPA|/ˈstaːrɪŋ/}} homophonous as {{IPA|[ˈstaːɾɪn]}} or {{IPA|[ˈstaːɹɪn]}}, but it can also apply across word boundaries, so that both ''but a'' {{IPA|/bət ə/}} and ''butter'' {{IPA|/ˈbətə/}} can be homophonous with ''borough'' {{IPA|/ˈbərə/}} as either {{IPA|[ˈbəɾə]}} or {{IPA|[ˈbəɹə]}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Collins|Mees|1990|pp=91–92}} ==See also== * [[Phonological history of the English language]] * [[Phonological history of English vowels]] * [[Rhotic and non-rhotic accents]] * [[l-vocalization|''L''-vocalization]] * [[Phonological history of wh|Phonological history of ''wh'']] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Bibliography == {{Refbegin}} * {{Citation |last1=Collins |first1=Beverley |last2=Mees |first2=Inger M. |editor-last1=Coupland |editor-first1=Nikolas |editor-last2=Thomas |editor-first2=Alan Richard |year=1990 |title=English in Wales: Diversity, Conflict, and Change |chapter=The Phonetics of Cardiff English |publisher=Multilingual Matters Ltd. |pages=87–103 |isbn=1-85359-032-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tPwYt3gVbu4C }} * {{Citation |last1=Watt |first1=Dominic |last2=Allen |first2=William |year=2003 |title=Tyneside English |journal=Journal of the International Phonetic Association |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=267–271 |doi=10.1017/S0025100303001397 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/231854084_Tyneside_English }} * [[John C. ([[Bachelor of Laws]], [[Master of Laws]]) |occupation = [[Politician]] · [[Civil service|Civil servant]] · [[Tax collector]] · [[Publishing|Publisher]] · [[Managing editor]] · [[Jurist]] · [[Historian]] · [[Board of directors|Corporate director]] · [[Board of directors|Nonprofit director]] · [[Author]] · [[Professor]] |signature = |website = }} '''Pieter Jacobus Oud''' (5 December 1886 – 12 August 1968) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] politician of the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (VVD) who held numerous political offices, including member of the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]], [[Minister of Finance]] and [[Burgermeester|Mayor]] of [[Rotterdam]]. He was a founding member of the [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]] (PvdA) and the [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] (VVD) which when on to become some of the most influential political parties in [[Politics of the Netherlands|Dutch politics]]. Before [[World War II]], he was member of the [[Social liberalism|left-liberal]] [[Free-thinking Democratic League]] (VDB). ==Life== ===Life before politics=== Oud came from a middle-class family, his father traded in tobacco, wine and, later, stocks and served as [[Wethouder|alderman]] in Purmerend. Oud attended [[Education in the Netherlands#History of education|HBS]] in [[Amsterdam]] graduating in 1904. He continued to study to become [[Civil law notary|notary]] between 1904 and 1907. During this time he had become member of the board of the League of Freethinking Propaganda Associations, the freethinking liberal youth organisation. He took a private courses in registration in [[Gorinchem]] between 1907 and 1909. Between 1909 and 1911 he was civil servant within the ministry of Finance responsible for registration and government possessions. In 1911 he became a tax collector on [[Texel]]. In 1912 he took his [[matriculation]] in order to study [[law]] at the [[University of Amsterdam]]. He combined his work as tax collector with his study of law. In the same year he married Johanna Cornelia Fischer, from this marriage they got one son. In 1914 he became tax collector in [[Ommen]]. Meanwhile, he was mobilised as Sergeant of the seventh regiment infantry, which was stationed near Amsterdam between 1914 and 1916. Between 1915 and 1919 he was member of the national board of the VDB. He graduated in 1917 on basis of a [[disputation]]. ===Political life=== ====For the VDB==== Oud was elected in [[Dutch general election, 1917|1917 elections]] for the VDB, the last election with [[Two-round system|runoff voting]], in the second round he beat the Staalman of the left-wing [[Christian Democratic Union (Netherlands)|Christian Democratic Party]] for the district of [[Den Helder]]. He retained his legal position as tax collector, but was given a leave for undetermined time. he was even promoted to inspector of finances in 1921, while on leave. In [[Dutch general election, 1918|1918]] Oud stood for elections again and was elected with 5,000 [[Voorkeurstem|preference votes]], mainly from the district of Den Helder. While MP, Oud also served as secretary of the VDB national board and editor of the ''De Vrijzinnige Democraat'', the party's magazine. In parliament Oud took a particular interest in military matters and education, and served as the party's finance spokesperson. As MP he served as member of the Committee on the Navy between 1923 and 1933 and the Committee on the Army since 1925. He was chairman of the Association for the promotion of Public Education "People's Education" for many years. In [[Dutch general election, 1933|1933]] Oud became Minister of Finance in the second cabinet led by [[Hendrik Colijn|Colijn]]. As minister he was responsible for a large scale operation of budget cuts, during a time of economic crisis. In 1935 he proposed the ''Bezuigingswet 1935'' (the Budget Cut law 1935) which involved many budget cuts and financial reorganisations: salaries of civil servants were cut, the old age pensions were financed in a different way and for budgetary reasons, soldiers were to become civil servants after a certain period. Although his proposals lead to a political crisis, they were nonetheless carried by parliament. In the same year, after [[Henri Marchant|Marchant]] left the VDB after a scandal, Oud succeeded him as political leader of the VDB. Oud [[Lijsttrekker|led]] the VDB in the [[Dutch general election, 1937|1937 elections]] and returned to the [[House of Representatives (Netherlands)|House of Representatives]] as [[Fractievoorzitter|chair of the parliamentary party]]. He also served as chair for the Committee on government expenditure. ====In Rotterdam==== He left the House of Representatives in 1938 to become [[List of mayors of Rotterdam|mayor]] of [[Rotterdam]]. As mayor he also served in the College of Curators of the University of Rotterdam and as chair of the Association of Dutch Municipalities. After he stepped down in 1952 he became honorary chairman of that association. In 1939 he was elected into the [[States-Provincial]] of [[South Holland]]. In August 1939 he was offered the position of Minister of Finance in the cabinet of [[Dirk Jan de Geer|De Geer]], but declined. Controversially, Oud did not resign after the [[Battle of the Netherlands|German invasion]] of 1940, although he was not a member of the [[National Socialist Movement in the Netherlands]] (NSB). During his period as mayor, he was involved in the reconstruction of the centre of Rotterdam which was destroyed by the German bombings. He was heavily criticised by Dutch politicians for cooperating too much with the NSB, while the NSB criticised him for being uncooperative. In the spring of 1941 he was harassed brutally by members of the NSB, twelve party-members invaded the City Hall, gagged Oud, adorned him with [[Freemasonry|Freemason]]-like symbols and made pictures of him. In the autumn of 1941 he resigned as mayor and he stood down as member of the States Provincial. He was succeeded by [[Frederik Ernst Müller]]. In the summer of 1942 he was briefly held in [[Sint-Michielsgestel]], where many prominent Dutch politicians were held captive. During the war Oud kept far from the [[Dutch resistance|resistance movement]] and instead committed himself to writing several books on parliamentary history. Meanwhile, he kept close contact with important people from the business and the political world of Rotterdam. In 1945, after the [[End of World War II in Europe|liberation of the Netherlands]], he returned to Rotterdam as mayor, although he was also asked to become [[List of mayors of Amsterdam|mayor]] of [[Amsterdam]], and he was officially re-appointed in 1946. In the same year the VDB merged with the social democratic [[Social Democratic Workers' Party (Netherlands)|SDAP]] and the left-wing Christian [[Christian Democratic Union (Netherlands)|CDU]] to form the [[Labour Party (Netherlands)|Labour Party]]. Oud was one of the co-founders of this party and served on the party's board between 1946 and 1947. Meanwhile, he served on many government, business, international and civil society committees, he chaired the government committee for municipal finances between 1946 and 1954, he was member of the [[board of trustees]] of the banker Staal, he was member of the pension council of the [[Dutch Reformed Church|Dutch Reformed]] Church since 1946 and he served as chair of the [[International Union of Municipalities and Local Governments]] between 1948 and 1954. ====For the VVD==== On 3 October 1947 Oud sent a letter to the board of the PvdA with which he resigned as a member. The reason he gave for the split was that the PvdA was moving too much into socialist waters, instead of being committed to progressive politics. The fact that he was refused a position on the party list for the [[Senate (Netherlands)|Senate]] is generally seen as the political reason for Oud's split. Oud never felt at home in the new social-democratic party. He immediately founded the Committee of Preparation of the Foundation of a Democratic People's Party, which prepared the foundation of the VVD. He negotiated the merger of the remnants of the old VDB with the newly founded [[Freedom Party (Netherlands)|Freedom Party]]. On 24 January 1948 he became one of the founding members of the liberal VVD, together with Stikker and Korthals and served in its first national board as vice-chair. In [[Dutch general election, 1948|1948]] he was elected to the House of Representatives for the VVD, and became chair of the VVD parliamentary party, he combined this position with the position of chair of the party's organisation. In parliament he mainly spoke on issues of administrative and constitutional law. He was a very influential member of parliament. When the law concerning the decolonisation of [[Indonesia]], a very controversial issue, was voted on, the two-thirds majority was only reached because of amendment proposed by Oud ensured the support of the VVD. In 1950-51 Oud came into conflict with the VVD's Minister of Foreign Affairs, Stikker, over the policy concerning [[New Guinea]]. Between 1950 and 1953 he was a member of the Government Committee Van Schaik, which prepared a constitutional change. In 1952 he did not seek to be reappointed as Rotterdam's mayor, and instead became extraordinary professor of [[Constitutional law|Constitutional]] [[Administrative law]] at the [[Erasmus University|University of Rotterdam]], which he remained until 1957. Between 1953 and 1963 he was chair of the Justice Committee of the House of Representatives. As such he was heavily involved in the preparation of many laws, and served as chair on the committees preparing the laws on the provinces, the police, archives, patents and many more. In 1959 he came into conflict with Van Riel, the chair of the VVD's parliamentary party in the Senate, because Van Riel wanted to become minister, but Oud denied him this. In the last years of his period in the House of Representatives, Oud was the eldest member of the House and on many times functioned as President, when a new president was elected for instance. Before the [[Dutch general election, 1963|1963 elections]] Oud announced that he would not continue as MP, he was succeeded by the Minister of Home Affairs [[Edzo Toxopeus]]. In the same year he was appointed as [[Minister of State#Other use|Minister of State]], an honorary title. ===Life after politics=== After 1963, Oud retired from Dutch political life. He was only asked upon at times of great crisis. In 1966 he was member of the committee, which advised government on the ministerial responsibility towards members of the [[Dutch royal house|royal house]], together with [[Willem Drees]]. In the same year, he co-authored a book on a new constitution. When Oud died in 1968, his family wanted to announce his death after the burial. His [[General Practitioner|GP]] did not know this, and told a patient that evening that Oud had died that afternoon. The father of this patient happened to be a journalist for the socialist paper [[Het Vrije Volk]], which published a large ''In Memoriam'' the next morning. ==Bibliography== * "Om de Democratie" (1929; "For Democracy") * "Het jongste verleden: Parlementaire geschiedenis van Nederland, 1918-1940" (1946; The recent past: parliamentary history of the Netherlands, 1918-194-) * "Honderd jaren: Hoofdzaken der Nederlandsche staatkundige geschiedenis, 1840-1940" (1946; One hundred years, Important matters of the Dutch political history 1840-1940) * "Het constitutionele recht van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden" (1947–1953; The constitutional law of the Kingdom of the Netherlands) * "Proeve van een Grondwet (1966; Attempt at a constitution) ==Quotes== *Oud was respected for his memory. During debates he could make remarks like: "You're saying this now, but eight years ago you said something totally different." *When asked whether the VVD would cooperate with the PvdA the coalition in a new government he showed his aversion to the party he had been a member of for one year like this: "Normal people don't cooperate with alcoholics in fighting alcoholism?" ==Trivia== *[[Jacobus Oud]], a famous Dutch architect, was his brother. *Oud was a respected voice in parliament, not only because he spoke with a soft high pitched voice, but also because he was the House's conscience when it came to constitutional issues and administrative laws. *He was made Knight of the [[Order of the Netherlands Lion]] in 1925 and received the Grand Cross of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]] in 1957. *Oud was a lifelong member of the freethinking Protestant broadcasting organisation, [[VPRO]]. ==Decorations== {| class="wikitable" style="width:60%;" |- style="background:#ccf; text-align:center;" | colspan=5 |'''Honours''' |- ! style="width:80px;"| Ribbon bar !! {{Redirect|Pop star|other uses|Popstar (disambiguation)|}} {{for|the British television series|Pop Idol}}
{{double image|right|Wolfgang-amadeus-mozart 1.jpg|150|Madonna, Rotterdam, 26-8-1987.jpg|137|Musical artists from [[Mozart]] to [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] have been credited as pop icons for their contributions to music.}}
A '''pop icon''' is a [[celebrity]], character or object whose exposure in [[popular culture]] is widely regarded as constituting a defining characteristic of a given society or era. The categorization is usually associated with elements such as longevity, [[Omnipresence|ubiquity]] and distinction. Moreover, "pop icon" status is distinguishable from other kinds of notoriety outside pop culture, such as with historic figures. Some historic figures are recognized as having reached "pop icon" status during their era, and such status may continue into the present. Pop icons of previous eras include [[Benjamin Franklin]]<ref name="Franklin">{{cite book | first = Joyce | last = Chaplin | title = The First Scientific American: Benjamin Franklin and the Pursuit of Genius | publisher = Basic Books | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-465-00955-7 }}</ref> and [[Mozart]].<ref name="Mozart">{{cite book | first = Bruno | last = Nettl | title = Heartland Excursions: Ethnomusicological Reflections on Schools of Music | publisher = University of Illinois Press | year = 1995 | isbn = 0-252-06468-2}}</ref>
== Longevity == Usually, the pop icon status of a celebrity is contingent upon longevity of notoriety.<ref name="dearborn000">{{cite book | first = Mary V. | last = Dearborn | title = Mailer: A Biography | publisher = Houghton Mifflin Books | date = December 9, 1999 | isbn = 978-0-395-73655-5 }}</ref><ref name="gottesman">{{cite book | editor1-first = Ronald | editor1-last = Gottesman | editor2-first = Richard Maxwell | editor2-last = Brown | title = Violence in America: An Encyclopedia | publisher = Simon and Schuster <!-- Are we sure it isn't Charles Scribner's Sons? --> | year = 1999 | isbn = 0-684-80487-5 }}</ref> This is in contrast to [[cult following|cult icons]], whose notoriety or recognition may be limited to a specific [[subculture]]. Some pop icons have left a lasting and indelible mark in the area of their career, and then went on to attain a lasting place of recognition in society at large.<ref name="Ratcliff">{{cite book | first = Ben | last = Ratcliff | title = The New York Times Essential Library: Jazz: A Critic's Guide to the 100 Most Important Recordings | publisher = Times Books | date = November 6, 2002 | isbn = 978-0-8050-7068-2 }}</ref>
== Ubiquity == A common element of pop icon status is the ubiquity of imagery and allusions to the iconic figure.{{#tag:ref|Kaku,<ref name="Kaku" /> p. 11 |group="note"}} It is common for the figure to be recognized and even celebrated in areas outside the original source of celebrity status.{{#tag:ref|See e.g., Kaku,<ref name="Kaku" /> Chaplin,<ref name="Franklin" /> ''et al.'' |group="note"}} An example of this is [[Albert Einstein]], a [[physicist]] whose image and legacy have been represented in comic strips, T-shirts, greeting cards and many other contexts.<ref name="Kaku">{{cite book | first = Michio | last = Kaku | authorlink= Michio Kaku | title = Einstein's Cosmos: How Albert Einstein's Vision Transformed Our Understanding of Space and Time | publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company]] |date=April 2004 | isbn = 978-0-393-05165-0}}</ref>
== Distinction == {{Refimprove section|date=August 2011}} Often pop icon status implies distinguished association with a societal ideal or [[archetype]]. It is not uncommon for iconic figures to have a [[nickname]] or [[sobriquet]] that is used to emphasize this association. Sometimes the very name of such individuals is even used as a synonym for common words or ideas.
Some pop icons, such as [[Mickey Mouse]],<ref name="Variety100">{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/index.asp?layout=variety100&content=jump2&jump=iconIndex|title=Icons of the century|date=|work=Variety100.com|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|accessdate=February 8, 2010|first=Dave|last=McNary}}</ref> [[Winnie the Pooh]], [[Bugs Bunny]],<ref name="Variety100"/> [[Superman]], [[Spider-Man]], [[Batman]], [[Darth Vader]], [[The X-Men]], [[Harry Potter]],<ref name="Schmidt">{{cite web|url=http://www.bluecorncomics.com/popicons.htm|title=The 200 Greatest Pop Culture Icons|last=Schmidt|first=Robert|date=February 24, 2004|work=Blue Corn Comics website|accessdate=February 8, 2010}}</ref> [[the Simpsons]],<ref name="Variety100"/> and even [[Sherlock Holmes]] are [[fictional character]]s. Even [[wikt:inanimate|inanimate]] objects have been recognized as pop icons.<ref name="Hammond">{{cite book | first = Mark | last = Vail | title = The Hammond Organ: Beauty in the B |edition=2nd | publisher = [[Backbeat Books]] | date = April 1, 2002 | isbn = 978-0-87930-705-9}} </ref><ref name="sheff">{{cite book | first = David | last = Sheff | title = Game Over: How Nintendo Zapped an American Industry, Captured Your Dollars, and Enslaved Your Children | publisher = [[Random House]] | date = April 27, 1993 | isbn = 978-0-679-40469-9 }}</ref><ref name="INHP1">{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.cr.nps.gov/nR/twhp/wwwlps/lessons/36liberty/36liberty.htm |title=The Liberty Bell: From Obscurity to Icon |work=Teaching with Historic Places |publisher=National Park Service|date=October 16, 2006}}</ref>
Some figures attain transitory or context-specific "pop icon" status for particular events that captivate public attention, such as in the case of the [[O.J. Simpson|O.J. Simpson trial]].<ref name="OJTrial">{{cite book | first = Max | last = Boot | authorlink=Max Boot | title = Out of Order: Arrogance, Corruption and Incompetence on the Bench | publisher = [[Basic Books]] | year = 1998 | isbn = 978-0-465-05375-9 }}</ref>
